abstract.text: Your app’s response to a request ride intent.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object contains your app’s response to a ride-booking request. After creating your response object, assign an appropriate object to the

property. The ride status object provides the details about how you handled the ride, including details about selected vehicle type, pricing, driver information, pickup time, pickup location, drop-off location, and so on. Siri and Maps display your response information to the user during the confirmation and booking phases.
Siri and Maps expect your response to contain a valid
object with information about the ride. Specifically, your status object must include a valid
object and you should always specify an activity object in the
property of your status object. When handling the intent, the
codes generate an error and should not be used.
methods of your handler object. For more information about implementing your handler object, see

abstract.text: Empower people to customize interactions for your app on their device.
Your response to an intent object.
A request to book the specified ride from your service.
The handler interface for booking a ride for the user.
Confirms that you can book the ride.
Handles the booking of the ride.
Your app’s response to a request ride intent.
The code indicating whether you successfully handled the intent.
Initializes the response object with the specified code and user activity object.
The current status of the ride.
Constants indicating the state of the response.
You are ready to handle the intent.
There is no specified response code.
Details about a type of ride offered by your ride-booking service.
The status of a ride booked through a ride-booking service.
A user activity object for canceling the ride request.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
